class.title: Principles of Accounting I
class.description: If enrolling in this course, you must have access to the Internet, e-mail and Microsoft Office software (97 or later version), including Word and Excel. Final exam must be taken at an approved monitored testing site. Go to http://ecampus.dcccd.edu and follow the login procedures to access the course. Use your seven-digit student I.D. number as both the username and password. For more information, contact Clarice McCoy at clariceMccoy@dcccd.edu or 972-860-4166.

class.title: Advanced Printmaking I
class.alt-description: An intensive, eleven-day workshop in monoprint processes with visiting artist, Clinton Cline, July 9-23, M-F, 9 a.m.- 5 p.m.. For additional information, please call Don Taylor at 972-860-4732.

class.title: Advanced Printmaking II
class.description: An intensive, 11-day workshop in monoprint processes with visiting artist, Clinton Cline. For additional information, please call Don Taylor at 972-860-4732.

class.title: Biology for Science Majors II
class.alt-description: BIOL 1406 is the prerequisite for BIOL 1407.

class.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I
class.description: Content includes biology in the modern world, DNA, genetics and the cell. The recommended on-campus orientation will be offered July 9 at 7 p.m. in Room K121. Online orientation is also available. Lectures, labs, most assignments, tests and quizzes are online, however, a midterm exam, lab practicals 1 and 2 and the final exam will be taken in the Testing Center or a pre- arranged alternate site.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: The subject is Mexico: A Cultural Perspective. E-mail Edleeca Thompson at eThompson@dcccd.edu. It is not possible to make a lateral transfer into other non-online sections. Additional information is on the Internet at http://ecampus.dcccd.edu. It is important that students provide the college with a current e-mail address.

class.title: Directed Studies
class.description: DIRS 9170 is a three-week course designed to give students the study skills and background to successfully complete SCIT 1407 and SCIT 1408, Anatomy and Physiology 1 and 2. Students who should take this course include those with limited background in biology and chemistry, who have been out of school for an extended period of time, or who desire an overview of Anatomy and Physiology.
class.alt-description: DIRS 9170 is a three-week course designed to give students the study skills and background to successfully complete SCIT 1407 and SCIT 1408, Anatomy and Physiology 1 and 2. Students who should take this course include those with limited background in biology and chemistry, who have been out of school for an extended period of time, or who desire an overview of Anatomy and Physiology.

class.title: Composition II
class.description: This course will examine literature concerning civil disobedience and nonviolent social movements in the 20th century. Readings, lectures, films, guest speakers and audio-visual presentations will help students gain a deeper understanding of the need for non-violence in their daily lives.
class.alt-description: This course will examine literature concerning civil disobedience and nonviolent social movements in the 20th century. Readings, lectures, films, guest speakers and audio-visual presentations will help students gain a deeper understanding of the need for non-violence in their daily lives.

class.title: World Lit
class.description: This course will explore what it means to be human. As students 'travel' through time and cultures, they will gain a greater understanding of how they relate as individuals to the larger world community.
class.alt-description: This course will explore what it means to be human. As students 'travel' through time and cultures, they will gain a greater understanding of how they relate as individuals to the larger world community.

class.title: Learning Framework
class.description: HDEV 1300 will help students develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include, but are not limited to: motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, test taking skills, reading/writing techniques, note taking, and the development of critical thinking skills.

course.title: Manage/Maintain Server 2003
course.long-title: Managing and Maintaining a Microsoft - Windows Server 2003 Environment

course.title: Spc Tpc/Cmptr/Info Science,gen
course.long-title: Special Topics in Computer and Information Sciences, General

class.title: Computer Literacy/Basic Skills
class.description: Computer Literacy is designed for the novice who has little or no experience with computers. In this six-session course you will practice using the mouse, learn about the components of the computer, including the keyboard and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing this course, you will be ready to enroll in Introduction to Computers/Windows XP or Windows Vista.
class.alt-description: Computer Literacy is designed for the novice who has little or no experience with computers. In this six-session course you will practice using the mouse, learn about the components of the computer, including the keyboard and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing this course, you will be ready to enroll in Introduction to Computers/Windows XP or Windows Vista.

class.title: Internet Part I
class.description: Internet Part I is a six-session course covering basic e-mail functions plus attachments. Students will learn to do searches using Google and other search engines. Other topics include addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and shopping/purchasing online. The class will use Microsoft Internet Explorer and also will discuss SBC/Yahoo, AOL and other browsers. Recommended prerequisite: Windows XP.
class.alt-description: Internet Part I is a six-session course covering basic e-mail functions plus attachments. Students will learn to do searches using Google and other search engines. Other topics include addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and shopping/purchasing online. The class will use Microsoft Internet Explorer and also will discuss SBC/Yahoo, AOL and other browsers. Recommended prerequisite: Windows XP.

class.title: Photoshop Elements 6, Part I
class.description: Photoshop Elements 6, Part I is a six-session course to help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Using the Photoshop Elements 6 software you will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red-eye removal. Recommended prerequisites: Windows XP and Beginning Internet.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements 6, Part I is a six-session course to help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Using the Photoshop Elements 6 software you will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red-eye removal. Recommended prerequisites: Windows XP and Beginning Internet.

class.title: Google for Genealogists, Pt II
class.description: Students will learn how to effectively use Gmail for genealogical mailing lists, ten techniques for writing genealogical queries that get results, Google Alerts and search book collections for digital images that will assist them in their genealogical research. Students will learn to view, navigate, extract, print and save information in online documents.
class.alt-description: Students will learn how to effectively use Gmail for genealogical mailing lists, ten techniques for writing genealogical queries that get results, Google Alerts and search book collections for digital images that will assist them in their genealogical research. Students will learn to view, navigate, extract, print and save information in online documents.

class.title: Beginning Lifetime Sports Act.
class.description: The beginning self defense course utilizes the Northern and Southern styles of Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach basic self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class.
class.alt-description: The beginning self defense course utilizes the Northern and Southern styles of Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach basic self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class.

class.title: Beginning Self Defense
class.description: The beginning self defense course utilizes the Northern and Southern styles of Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach basic self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class. at first class.

class.title: Inter Self Defense
class.description: The intermediate self defense course utilizes the Northern and Southern styles of Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach advanced self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class.
class.alt-description: The intermediate self defense course utilizes the Northern and Southern styles of Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach advanced self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class.

class.title: Inter Physical Fitness
class.description: It is highly recommended that a student complete PHED 1164 prior to enrollment in the intermediate physical fitness course. This course offers continuation of a total fitness package including physical fitness assessment with computer printout, weight training, aerobic activities and wellness concepts.
